text: If you'd like to test the actual meta description you want, you can use the nosnippet tag surrounding the text that it currently shows as meta, and do that until it actually shows yours. But there's also a chance that your meta has to be changed to better reflect what's on the page.

elements.text: If you'd like to test the actual meta description you want, you can use the nosnippet tag surrounding the text that it currently shows as meta, and do that until it actually shows yours. But there's also a chance that your meta has to be changed to better reflect what's on the page.

text: Hey, everyone! So I've been freelance writing for over 13 years, and I recently purchased the Guru plan of SEMRush for a one-off project I did for a client (big keyword and competitive analysis project) as well as build the author website for my latest book launch. I found it so helpful in what I do day-to-day as a writer (seeing how my content ranks and then using that for demonstrating value in future proposals), that I'm continuing the subscription. It's not cheap, however, and I'm wondering what I could possibly do to get more value out of it as a freelancer. Most of my clients provide me briefs that they've created from it, so the SEO work is already done. But for new clients or clients that aren't using tools, is there something a freelance writer could bring to the table having their own SEM Rush account? So far, it seems to have more of a value for people that advertise as agencies, and I'm trying to remain a freelancer at this point. I'm trying to justify keeping it -- even though I love it so much.

elements.text: Hey, everyone! So I've been freelance writing for over 13 years, and I recently purchased the Guru plan of SEMRush for a one-off project I did for a client (big keyword and competitive analysis project) as well as build the author website for my latest book launch. I found it so helpful in what I do day-to-day as a writer (seeing how my content ranks and then using that for demonstrating value in future proposals), that I'm continuing the subscription. It's not cheap, however, and I'm wondering what I could possibly do to get more value out of it as a freelancer. Most of my clients provide me briefs that they've created from it, so the SEO work is already done. But for new clients or clients that aren't using tools, is there something a freelance writer could bring to the table having their own SEM Rush account? So far, it seems to have more of a value for people that advertise as agencies, and I'm trying to remain a freelancer at this point. I'm trying to justify keeping it -- even though I love it so much.

text: I think if you're already writing, moving into a larger role as a content strategist and starting to recommend the articles you're going to work on (and getting paid extra for that) is the next logical step. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: I think if you're already writing, moving into a larger role as a content strategist and starting to recommend the articles you're going to work on (and getting paid extra for that) is the next logical step.

text: Thank you. I think that may be the way to go, as well. Are companies generally warm to this offering from a freelancer? Or do you think it's something associated with a content agency? I just want to be sure I'm not stepping into a niche where I have to create a large team to be taken seriously.

elements.text: Thank you. I think that may be the way to go, as well. Are companies generally warm to this offering from a freelancer? Or do you think it's something associated with a content agency? I just want to be sure I'm not stepping into a niche where I have to create a large team to be taken seriously.

text: I think it depends! I'd love it if the person writing contributed a few ideas and then asked if it would make sense to put together a 6-12 month content strategy and pitch that.

elements.text: I think it depends! I'd love it if the person writing contributed a few ideas and then asked if it would make sense to put together a 6-12 month content strategy and pitch that.

text: You probably know the business better than whatever SEO person they've had put the content strategy together so why not have it be you?

elements.text: You probably know the business better than whatever SEO person they've had put the content strategy together so why not have it be you?

text: Food for thought. Thanks so much. I've been comfortable doing the same things for years now, but I'm growing bored, and while I'm making good money, more and more of my writing jobs have content strategists coming between me and the editor. You are right. This is exactly what I needed to hear!
